Description: Diademed head of Ptolemy VI, right. (obverse)
Eagle standing left on thunderbolt; left field, dolphin. (reverse)
Curator's comments: Walker & Higgs 2001 Like his father before him, Ptolemy VI was a minor at the time of his inheritance of the Egyptian throne. During his early years his mother, Cleopatra I, served as his regent, and her portrait has been discerned by some scholars in the representation of Isis on a series of bronze coins produced at Alexandria (Walker & Higgs, cat. no. 88). The portrait of the young king was placed on some bronze issues (cat. no. 89), as well as spectacular gold coinage (cat. no. 77).
Bibliographic references: Svoronos 1904 / Τα Νομισματα του Κρατους των Πτολεμαιων (The Coins of the Ptolemaic Kings) (1488)
Walker & Higgs 2001 / Cleopatra of Egypt: from History to Myth (89)
